clusters.title: 'Beautiful' young man among pair mourned after fatal Melbourne attacks
clusters.neutral_headline: Two Children Killed in Melbourne Stabbing

items.title: 'Beautiful' young man among pair mourned after fatal Melbourne attacks
items.standfirst: A 15-year-old boy killed as he made his way home from playing basketball is being mourned as police investigate the fatal stabbing of two children in Melbourne's outer-west on Saturday night.
items.content: A 15-year-old boy killed as he made his way home from playing basketball is being mourned as police investigate the fatal stabbing of two children in Melbourne's outer-west on Saturday night.

items.title: Police probe potential mistaken identity after two kids stabbed to death
items.standfirst: Two boys killed in a suspected machete attack in Melbourne's west were on their way home from basketball when they were ambushed in a potential case of mistake identity.
items.content: Two boys killed in a suspected machete attack in Melbourne's west were on their way home from basketball when they were ambushed in a potential case of mistaken identity.Dau Akueng, 15, and Chol Achiek, 12, were walking from a bus stop in Cobblebank with a third friend just before 8pm yesterday when they were set upon by up to eight masked people. The pair were found critically injured on the street about 200 metres apart in what police have described as having "the hallmarks of a youth gang crime". Neighbours reported hearing their screams and rushed outside to help but it was too late." It's absolutely shocking that not one, but two could happen so close to home, at 8 o'clock at night," one neighbour told 9News.Police said the victims weren't gang members and were investigating if their deaths were a horrific case of mistaken identity.The boy's grieving family and friends are pleading for justice.Dau's father said he needed answers for his son."This is a basketball player, he's not a criminal," Elbino Akueng said."I'm talking on behalf of my community, this is happening to us.READ MORE: Man dies after early morning shooting in Melbourne's CBD"In the last month, we have buried four kids, similar incidents keep happening, but there's no answer from police." Emergency services first found Chol, who paramedics tried to resuscitate but couldn't save.Chol's father, Cauti Nuong, described him as a "good boy" who was very clever."Very intelligent, he's always so active," he told 9News. Detective Inspector Graham Banks said Dau, 15, was found dead a short time later nearby on Cobble Street as a result of "significant injuries consistent with being stabbed".He added that Chol and Dau were not gang members. READ MORE: Beaches closed after surfer killed in shark attack"Both murders are linked to the same offenders," Banks said."Witness and CCTV vision shows the murders were committed by a large group of male offenders who appear to be covered with face masks."They fled the scene in a vehicle that is yet to be identified and vision shows that they were armed with machetes."While the investigation is in its early stages, police believe the attacks have "the hallmarks of a youth gang crime"."It is one of the most horrific crimes in a substantial and growing list of crimes of this nature," Banks said."Police are appealing for witnesses to come forward and that includes people who will know these offenders."Given the time of night, it will be anticipated that a number of vehicles were around that vicinity and enough of those cars will have dashcam footage.READ MORE:Teenage boy dies after 'stolen car' crashes during police pursuit "We appeal for people who will have knowledge of this crime and that will include people known to the offenders to come forward."You can do it anonymously but you can also report it formally."Banks said police would work to determine a motive for the stabbings."When we see crimes of this nature sometimes occur, there has been occasion where people have been targeted by mistaken identity," Banks said."There is potential that the offenders know these people and they've been specifically targeted as well, but there's also clearly a possibility that it's been a case of mistaken identity and that this is what has occurred." READ MORE: China criticises Australian and Canadian warships transiting Taiwan Strait The masked men are believed to be older than the victims. Dau has been remembered as a bright and talented young basketballer. Collingwood Basketball Association (CBA) general manager Trent Pearson said he was a "much-loved member" of the club."He was a highly talented player and referee with a cheerful personality who touched all those he interacted with over many years," Pearson said."Dau had a smile and confidence that were infectious and his love for basketball and being around his friends will be sorely missed.""As a club we are devastated by his passing. I've spoken today to the family and our focus now, is supporting them and our club members in coming to terms with the tragic loss of a beautiful young man."CBA vice president Duré De Winter said Dau "brightened everyone's day with his smile" and spoke of his maturity on and off the court." We are heartbroken to lose such a beautiful young man. Our thoughts and condolences go to his family and community, they are a strong and beautiful community," Winter said."We are so sorry for their loss."Police and the NSW State Emergency Service spent the night in the street gathering evidence. "The exact circumstances surrounding the deaths are still being determined but are believed to be connected," Victoria Police said in a statement earlier today."At this time police are treating it as a targeted attack and the investigation remains ongoing."Anyone with information is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: Two children were fatally stabbed in Melbourne's outer-west.
Police are investigating the incident as a potential case of mistaken identity.
The victims were on their way home from playing basketball.
A 15-year-old boy was among those killed in the attacks.
The attacks occurred on Saturday night.

items.title: Friend describes 'heroic' final act of Sydney surfer killed in shark attack
